content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Very interesting premise with a clear statement. Even people with no idea about luminance computation (includes me) can figure out enough just from the statement alone.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Even though the full math is required for some people who aren't doing well.  There is enough detail to finish the clash in 5 minutes or less.

Maybe you could finesse your explanation to make it sound more mathematical to less experienced people with maybe 2 sentences rather than 1.  Other than that it is perfect.  Maybe explain what luminance is and talk about rounding more for the inexperienced.

Give an example and do the math like some other clashes.

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: This contribution is not suitable for a clash of code because:
- there are too many rounding constraints to be pleasant to play during a clash as Visual dev says
-The instruction is not very clear.
-And the .2f format. Just stop

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I accept this contribution

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: too much rounding constraints for being nice to play during a clash

Goal section
* After reading the explanation, I still don't understand how to connect the concepts of "max luminance" and "min luminance" to the two colors. Your solution code seems to suggest no max/min functions are required.
* I also can't see any explanation which connects "relative luminance" to the contrast equation.

Constraints section
* r, g, b, c are not defined in Input or Output sections.

Stub generator
* Instead of providing two strings, please provide integers using loopline explained here:
https://www.codingame.com/playgrounds/40701/help-center/stub-generator

Thanks.

Thanks for the feedback! I went ahead and revised the description to make the connections between contrast and relative luminance a bit clearer.

As for using loopline in the stub, I am not seeing how to make a clean stub with that command, but it's probably just me, since it's my first time contributing here. I would assume it would be something like this: 

loopline 1 red:int green:int blue:int 
loopline 1 red2:int green2:int blue2:int

or

loopline 2 red:int green:int blue:int

but both seem pretty messy compared to the string input I had before. Any thoughts?

EDIT: 
I switched it to a read command that reads the three ints on two lines instead of the string based input I had before. This seems cleaner than the loopline commands, but again, maybe I am missing something there.

ok, Thank you. The goal is now clearer, and your stub generator works too! Now you just have to add [[C]] in the Output section so that it is properly defined.

(Just to explain a bit: I understand that the Goal section states C, but it reads more like a formula and it does not contain the R, G, B variables either. That's why I make the above suggestion.)
Got it! Thanks again for the suggestions. I fixed the output section.
